text: hi everyone I'm Jackie I am the head of front-end development at behance which
is an online platform for showcasing and discovering creative work you can reach
me at any point online on Twitter at Jackie backwards which is a tricky username to try and communicate out loud
also be doing Q&A at the end of this session I'll try and take questions from
you guys in person but I also thought I'd try something new and try slide oh I've never used it before but if you go
to that URL and put in code eight five three zero you can actually submit questions during the talk and then I'll
have a look at the end and go through some of those as well so today I want to
tell you a bit about B Hans's journey growing and maintaining a large code
base in an era where front-end technology is advancing and changing extremely fast from our days of vanilla
CSS through the introduction of pre processors and all the way into our current day CSS in jeaious
implementations I'll go over some of our trials and tribulations our growing
pains and I will even air some of our dirty laundry but perhaps most
importantly how I learned to stop worrying and love the website so the
front-end web development ecosystem is moving insanely fast these days it seems
like a new tool or methodology for authoring HTML CSS and JavaScript is becoming available seemingly every
single day whereas a few years ago there weren't nearly as many tools with which
to work on these things probably in large part because complex things like responsive web development or single
page web apps weren't concerns anywhere close to our radar yet but now of course
we're seeing huge rapid advancements in everything from the languages themselves to how we generate basically every type
of code that we write to the frameworks we use to organize our code all the way to the build tools that we use to
compile optimize and serve our code and because there is always some better or
faster tool becoming available to use it can feel a little overwhelming having to choose and adopt
the best new technologies all the time now this is hard enough to do in a brand
new project where there are no pre-existing code considerations but it can be especially hard in a large code
base or one that has existed for a long time where when the moment you add something new now suddenly everything
else becomes legacy code and now not only do you have a whole new set of code to learn and maintain you also have to
consider how it's going to work with all of this old code as well as how or even if you're ever going to update this
legacy code to use the new stuff and when you compound these technical
challenges with this industry pressure that you should be using certain tools or doing things a certain way in order
to be a real developer it can create kind of a harsh environment for being able to make the best decisions for your
team and for your product and for your users which on the code side can lead to
things like 'we increased technical debt or missed project deadlines and on the
human side of things can need lead to negative things like feeling imposter syndrome or even worse burnout of course
it's super easy to compare ourselves in our work to others especially in an era where social media fosters so much
information overload we see other websites or hear other opinions about the best way to do things and we think
that's better than mine or my website will never be that good or I'll never be as smart as that person but making this
kind of comparison is kind of like comparing your life to someone's Instagram life it's unrealistic to
compare your reality to a highly curated projection we all have way too much
information about our own situations and not enough information about theirs so
what I want to do today is pull back the curtain on be Hans's Instagram life as
it were and show you the real side of our team's web development journey over
the years and how we've faced all these different challenges so if you feel like
you've ever experienced these kinds of shoes or challenges or anything like them or might ever experience them I
want you to know you're not alone so we've been evolving be Hans's codebase
since 2010 when I joined the team eight years ago they had just finished a
wholesale rewrite of the website from scratch but since then we've been working with the same one evolving
codebase we've moved through different templating engines CSS preprocessors and
a countless number of JavaScript libraries and frameworks I joined as the
fifth developer and since then our dev team has grown to be about 40 people and
for me personally although I started as a general front-end developer and was working kind of doing a little bit of
everything across the whole stack I have grown into focusing almost entirely on
our CSS I work really closely with our designers and also thinking about how we structure and architect our CSS across
our different products so and all the time we've dealt with a wide variety of
challenges we are constantly considering which new technologies can serve us and
the website and our users needs best we have a number of times had to figure out
how to integrate new technology into old even when there were massive functional
disparities we've had to determine when to actually start implementing these
things in particular balancing our product goals and roadmap with things like developer happiness and the health
of the codebase and of course we've had to figure out how to clean up any messes
we left behind along the way so there
are a lot of opinions out there on what the best or the right way to build a website is I'm not here to tell you that
there is any right or wrong way to do any of these things in fact I'm kind of
here to demonstrate the opposite what I do want to tell you is how we've handled these challenges why we made the
different decisions that we and how they did or didn't work out for us and I want to do this as kinds of a
means to reveal that no matter how pretty and put together things may look from the outside when you pull back the
curtain the reality is no website or process is ever really as perfect as it
may seem so first a little insight into
be Hans's size and complexity if you're not familiar with Behance it's a
platform for showcasing and discovering creative work which means that artists can come to our website and upload lots
of different types of media everything from images to video to audio to just plain text if that's what suits
them and then we display their work and make it easy to be discovered by others
through a variety of ways so for example your work could be featured on our homepage
it could be displayed in one of our curated galleries or it could even be surfaced through a feed of content that
is automatically generated just by following different people on the website we have user profiles we have
team profiles we have a job list for finding creative careers and hiring creatives we have a pretty robust inbox
messaging and notification system and there's even a section of the website that where we stream live video almost
24/7 just to name a few parts of the site so as of today I counted about 50
pages on the website existing in various states of logged in or out and that is
made up of over 500 JavaScript files and about the same number of style sheets
and almost a thousand markup templates so this number has been flux been in
flux over the years as we've you know added and removed various pages and features from the website but the site
itself is also evolving to become more like a web app as opposed to a traditional individual paged website for
example like I mentioned we now have interactive modular components such as our notifications feed and our messages
feed that exist and can be seen from anywhere on the site as well as things like a project
pop-up or a user card that can be incited from lots of different areas of the website as well but we have very
humble beginnings back in 2010 when I first joined we weren't using anything
other than vanilla CSS to style the website it's probably safe to say that
at that time you could describe our CSS development style as copy/paste driven
development because we had no tools on the front end to help us reduce repetition we weren't even using any
kind of methodologies or naming conventions to help simplify things so
this is what the website looked like when I first joined the team this is a screenshot from the wayback machine
there used to be something on the side there but some things are lost even to the Internet and I would say that
anything that you see on the website that wasn't like plain system font text or a solid color was probably made with
an image and this was because CSS wasn't nearly as robust as it is today and we
were trying to create something more visually interesting than we could actually do with native CSS at the time
now over time we started to get comfortable using CSS features for
visual flair where we could understanding that the website didn't have to look exactly the same in every
single browser and honestly once the designers learned that we could make as many CSS gradients as we wanted without
having to make images for them I got to become very intimately familiar with this tool it takes a lot of different
vendor prefixes and syntaxes to create a CSS gradient back in those days and I certainly was not about to memorize that
syntax so in time as browser technology was starting to pick up more steam CSS
as a language was advancing we were really having fun with a lot of the cool
CSS visual treats and tricks that we could do with native CSS and we were
getting more comfortable moving away from using images from things that we could now do with just CSS we had an interesting
additional challenge as well in that we also had these offshoots of Behance that
were themed galleries for different creative fields and these almost like white label miniature be Hans's for
different schools and organizations and now all of these used the same markup
and styles and JavaScript as the main Behance website just with additional style sheets loaded on top of them to
customize each one for the look and feel of their brand or its creative field again all of this lived within one code
base which of course meant that if you were changing something on the main behance website you then had to go and
make sure that you didn't break anything on any of these other 40-plus other websites that were built on top of that
it's kind of intense so by now we had a pretty clear need for a tool
that was going to help us with our CSS development not only were vendor prefixes slipping through the cracks
having to handwrite them all the time but thanks to all of these themed sites and galleries we were absolutely
inundated with copy pasted CSS especially where the only differences
were things like font names or color values fortunately for us
by this time CSS preprocessors were really picking up steam and looking like they were going to be the perfect tools
to help us whip our CSS into shape now the story I'm about to tell is not
about the merits of any one CSS preprocessor over the other but I do want to use it as a real-world example
of the messy path to choosing implementing and actually using new tools so we were debating between sass
and less both great tools on their own but we had to do proper due diligence
and make sure that we pick the one the right one for our needs ultimately sass
had more compelling implementations and features for our specific use cases encompass on top of that offered us a
ton of extra power that was going to be absolutely perfect for theming needs and for sprite
management I mean we were super excited about it Stassen compass were set to change our
lives the answer could not have been more clear we obviously went with less but why
would we do that well in our case we went with less for a couple of reasons at the time there was only Ruby sass and
since behance was not built on a ruby stack it wasn't easy for us to implement
or even get started using or trying sass where I was on the flip side less could
be really easily compiled by a very convenient little GUI app that you could just download to your computer which
meant that it had a much lower barrier to entry for us we were still an extremely small dev team at this time
and this meant that we could start getting the benefits of a preprocessor much sooner and with less friction and
less engineering time than if we had actually put in the time to try and figure out how to use sass at that point
it afforded us another benefit to though and that we were actually able to use less as a proof of concept that
implementing a CSS preprocessor was a worthwhile investment the time it took
to implement it the time it starts to implement it to get it up and running for everyone to use paid off drastically
in development and improvement time down the line which then meant that we were
able to get team buy-in for adopting sass as well as negotiate for the development time needed to do so and
ultimately make the switch to the tool that we felt would suit us best but our
journey does not end there although we had decided the higher investment in setting up sass was worth it we did have
to cut some corners to get there to complicate things we were now dealing with the dreaded
technical debt of having a code base that was partially vanilla CSS and partially less syntax so we would have
to take the time to convert both of those into sass and we still didn't have a stack that could compile sass for us
traditionally sass was compiled as part of the lake whole Ruby on Rails asset
pipeline and we didn't have anything like that but what we could do was install Ruby and sass on each of our
individual machines and compile and commit the sass and the CSS to the
repository from there now we violated a
lot of web development best practices by compiling CSS on our own machines
instead of with a build tool on top of that we were committing an even worse
crime of actually committing compiled code to our repository now I highly
doubt you'd ever find a medium think piece advocating for this kind of implementation and I admit it gives me
some anxiety to stand on stage and admit in front of this many engineers that we
were committing such egregious violations of best practices by having
literally hundreds of compiled CSS files in our repository but on the flip side I
also cannot overstate how much benefit we were getting by having sass available to us for what sounds like a nightmare
situation on the surface I have to say for the most part actually works pretty well for us suddenly we were able to
build our themed galleries and white labeled sites in a fraction of the time which meant that we were helping our
users in our mission to give more exposure to creatives we were able to do
it with much less code than before which meant that the codebase became easier to understand and maintain although
committing compiled code is considered a bad practice for a large code base with
a lot of interdependencies it actually gave us extremely clear visibility into the reach that any individual change was
actually having and on top of all that it also meant that we had tools that
could do some grunt work for us so for example our designers could spend time actually designing things and focusing
on the things that mattered as opposed to spending time doing menial tasks like stitching sprites together so in this
case we were able to find a pretty good balance between a subpar tech uncle implementation with overwhelming
developer and designer happiness as well as code health by reducing a lot of our CSS technical debt and increasing our
development speed but what happens when you need a tool that doesn't seem to exist yet
it was around this time that we started work on a new product it was a single page web app for task management that we
called action method online being that it was a brand-new product that we were starting from scratch we had a rare and
excellent opportunity to try out new technologies without having to worry about retrofitting any existing code
into any new paradigms or anything like that so we stuck with sass for the styles but on the JavaScript
side we actually made the decision to write our own JavaScript MVC framework which we called NBD jeaious and we built
this at a time when angular and backbone were actually pretty popular and kind of established MVC frameworks so why would
we bother with our own right but if you look at the timeline you can actually see that we were doing this when there
weren't a ton of alternative options or the ones that did exist were fairly new and adopting young technology in a
product that you anticipate or hope it's going to live on for years it's kind of a non zero risk move now I'm not saying
that writing your own framework or using an existing one is better or worse than the other but for the size of our team
which was still pretty small and the needs of our product being able to iterate on our own front-end framework
was precisely what we needed at the time and what ended up happening is that
action method online actually became a really good proving ground for NBD because it was born and forged for
specific interactive and data-driven purposes we were able to apply the techniques and practices that we learned
their back on Behance and we're able to start using it for some of the more complex content uploading and editing
features that we were starting to build on Behance as well by this time the
hands was evolving from its static website roots to become more modular and responsive now executing this kind of
huge paradigm shift was really big undertaking for us basically
nothing about how the site was designed or built to that point was conducive to being responsive the way we built the
layout was completely rigid the existing design was not immediately adaptable to smaller screen sizes
there was no design system in place to even like organise this kind of massive visual update around and most of all we
certainly were lacking the front-end tools that we needed to cleanly structure and implement the kind of responsive functionality that we really
wanted to build so while we knew we wanted to make the website responsive
despite the challenges in place by the existing foundation we knew that a full rewrite was simply out of the question
we were still a small team and we wanted to get something out to production to our users faster than a full rewrite
would allow so we had to come up with a different strategy so this was always
started work on our first ever pattern librarian style guide we did this with
the intention that the modular reusable components would help us in our endeavor to update the website to be responsive
in smaller chunks and get things out the door quicker as opposed to doing a more monolithic rewrite so today you probably
hear a lot of talk about design systems but I would say the idea of a fully comprehensive design system hadn't
really made it big yet at this point but pattern libraries were really popular it
was around this time that Twitter bootstrap was really hitting its stride and setting a strong precedent and not
only that but it seemed like the DRI principle of software development or
don't repeat yourself was actually really starting to make its way into the ethos of CSS development as well and
pattern libraries and style guides were actually really well suited to help enforce this paradigm not only on the
code side but also across the developer designer barrier and once again since we
already had a fully designed and built websites that we were not starting over from scratch on retrofitting a complete
comprehensive design system would have been entirely impractical anyway both from a design perspective Anna
developmen perspective but we knew that modularity and colonialization was going to help us
a lot in the efforts that we were making to make me hands go from a non responsive to responsive website so we
built these modular components we displayed them neatly in a style guide that you could view within the Behance
website we built them using moustache sass and our NBD JavaScript framework we
even started our own internal sass library that we call Giuliana and these
new components were mostly new in the code sense visually they matched the
existing components on the site which meant that as we updated different pages of the site we could replace the old UI
components with the new ones that we built in this pattern library basically meaning that any time someone had
handwritten out the code you know with the markup and class names to build a UI element before we could swap it out with
this new shared component pretty easily and then on top of that as a matter of dealing directly with technical debt we
would also sometimes just carve out specific time with the sole purpose of ripping out all code and replacing it
with these new components now this was all just like part of what it took to
make the site responsive and even still I would say that the whole process of converting the site probably took a
couple of years the reality of the route that we chose is also that if you were
browsing the website on a small device during this time you may end up with two vastly different experiences on the
website sometimes you may see a page that is perfectly optimized for your small device and then while navigating
you may suddenly land on very large unwieldy desktop optimized page now once
again I doubt that you would ever find an article suggesting that having some
pages be responsive and other pages not be responsive is a particularly good user experience but we have to find a
balance between a lot of different factors and that's everything from our roadmap of products and features that we
want to work on up coming to the time that we need to spend on technical debt or other features that aren't user
facing to stakeholder interests to the benefit that we can provide our
users in any given amount of time so while it may seem like an obvious choice
to give the user the best experience possible by doing a wholesale rewrite of
the website and delivering one comprehensive complete responsive experience all at once decisions like
that are just never made in a vacuum for us taking into consideration a ton of
different factors and variables a piecemeal implementation was the best route and ultimately I have to say I
think it worked out although yes it may have been kind of weird for some users
sometimes some of the time we prioritized highest traffic page first
so hopefully we were reducing the chances of that happening and also to
the best of my knowledge like none of our users were so upset or scared off that they you know stopped using Behance
because we had this non-ideal implementation along the way so anyway
back to the code side of things at this point we had a pretty robust toolkit on
our hands it's an interesting mix of open source and homegrown but we've got mustache for our reusable markup
templates we have sass compass and our giuliana library for our modular reusable CSS and we're using NBD HIAS
and requirejs for our modular javascript and these
tools carried us well into about 2015 when we started work on another brand
new single page web app this time it's a website builder called adobe portfolio
which stood to be the most complex web application that we've built still to
date we had a lot of new technical challenges on portfolio that we had
never dealt with before we wanted to build a full GUI what-you-see-is-what-you-get website
editor where the user didn't have to code anything at all and by using any
one of literally hundreds customization dialogues the user could change their site and see it reflected
in the editor in real-time and we wanted to do all of this all while maintaining
an editor chrome that needed to not interfere or intersect with the user customizations in any way so although
this product was totally different from behance there was actually some technical
challenge overlap that needed to be solved that would benefit similar circumstances on behance as well in
particular being able to have components that didn't conflict or interact as well
as some of the more complex content uploading and editing features so we
started building portfolio with these tools but building and maintaining your own tools it's not without its downsides
and risks either so by now we'd really been starting to feel some of the
growing pains of our homegrown frameworks on libraries with our SAS
library Juliana in particular it had actually become so over engineered that
nobody even wanted to use it anymore I think there was this mentality that since it was a library that we
controlled for our own uses and our own products we felt compelled to make it as useful for any potential use case as
possible which mostly did nothing but lead directly to massively over-engineered code not only that
because of how we had set it up it was actually so difficult to update and distribute the package that nobody even
wanted to put in the effort to try and clean that code up it meant that it was just so much easier and cleaner to
create whatever new mixin or function or whatever it was that you needed right in
the code that you were working on and should you need it in one of the other applications just copy and paste it over
there as well we also came to learn a
lot about the practical realities of using and maintaining your own JavaScript framework across an entire
website so MBD was originally built by just one of our developers and
maintained by only an additional couple more of them so this meant that it didn't move
particularly fast other open source frameworks were advancing at a much higher rate our team was still very
small at this point can't believe there would have even been more than like five people working on it so that meant that
not only were we missing out on the benefits that these open source advancements could give our products but
we would have been losing time if we had tried to implement the same or similar features back into our framework it also
meant that we found it was much more challenging for new hires to learn it
documentation on NBD was sparse because the developers a weren't technical
writers and B they were mostly busy spending their time developing either of
the framework or features for our products and that meant that the universe of resources to get help was
scoped entirely to a very small portion of our dev team which of course then
made it much harder to be self-sufficient if you were someone trying to learn this framework for the first time on the flipside popular open
source frameworks came with the benefit of way more active and visible communities to tap into for help
which not only meant that you have a way bigger pool of resources to get help from but it also means that there is an
active community that you can give back to when you solve a challenging issue with something as well
so by then it was pretty easy for us to acknowledge that these homegrown tools were no longer the best tools for our
team or for the new types of products and features that we were building now they had worked for us for a long
time and in some ways they still were there is no one day that you wake up and
show up to work and realize this is it this is the exact moment that this tool
has stopped being useful 100% for our product there's a long tail of changing
needs and considerations that goes into whether or not something is working for your team and for your product up to
this point we've done well adopting modular JavaScript with NBD and require we've done the best that we could scope
and component izing our CSS as much as possible using the BEM methodology and
some different sass features but over time the scope the truly scopes nature
of burgeoning CSS and jeaious tools and frameworks was becoming impossibly enticing for our increasingly modular
websites and web apps and our current tools were simply becoming outdated in our evolving products and our advancing
needs now we had sort of an interesting perfect storm of timing for our team
after spending some time focusing on Adobe portfolios development we split
some of the team off and gave our attention back to Behance we'd been feeling the need for some more advanced
tech on portfolio and in the time that we had been building it our designers had actually been working on a whole new
look and feel for the entire behance website we wanted this to make a big
splash we wanted it to be a huge release to the world that would change the look
of pretty much every single page on the website all at once but once again
without starting the whole thing over from scratch it simply would have taken way too long the benefit wasn't there
interestingly this time around it was a more widespread update than when we had
converted the site to be responsive whereas previously we were making
individual pages or groups of pages to be responsive this time not only were we
changing the look of components that were being used across the website we also wanted to change the fundamental
underlying code and we wanted the whole site to get the benefit of this update all at once so with a big overhaul on
our plates and a technical need to fill on portfolio the time was once again ripe for us to look towards new
technology now in the same way that the industry at large has opinions about the
best tools to use so does any given dev team so what we did was we held group
discussions lunch and learns knowledge sharing for anyone who was interested where we
would discuss the pros and cons of seemingly every JavaScript and scope CSS
solution Under the Sun and we would actually try out the best candidates in
the admin section of our websites which are just kind of like a back-end area of the website that only employees could
access but we're really useful as a means of giving us a near real-world
proving ground for these different tools ultimately we decided on view and CSS
modules for this new task but by now the story probably is starting to sound
pretty familiar we've come full circle on needing new tools investigating new
tools choosing new tools and then of course actually implementing them and
although the specific technical implementation details may differ the
ideas and methods that we use to actually get the job done are pretty much the same we exclusively built new
features using these new tools and frameworks which meant that we could start using them immediately we rebuilt
the existing UI components alongside their existing implementations which
could then be put into use as different parts of the website were updated and perhaps most critically we did all of
this behind what we call feature flags which is basically just a check in the
code that serves one set of code or another depending on your users gatekeeper setting which meant that we
could build all of this alongside the existing website without interfering with it while also still having the
ability to see all of this new stuff in action in production before it was actually ready for its public debut and
this actually brings us to where we are today the website is not fully converted
but we continue to follow the same practices as we update and develop new
features as an interesting aside although we are fairly recently into our
transition into we've actually recently made the decision to switch to react we haven't
started using it on Behance yet but we intend to start soon and I bring this up to illustrate kind of a different point
than any I've been able to make yet which is that sometimes depending on
your situation decisions are bigger than just your team and your website so in our case for us
at Adobe there is a broader movement to get the different web teams within Adobe
using the same framework so that we operate in less isolation and cut knowledge share across teams more easily
this means that we can help obviously not only our team and our products but other teams and products in the

makes sense so if you look at the arc of
front-end development on Behance over the last eight years it's changed pretty drastically in 2010 our biggest

not only are we concerned about how the website looks but we also have to consider how to optimize our code for
